thread.title: Why the Brownlow already has an early frontrunner
thread.title_full: Why the Brownlow already has an early frontrunner

title: Why the Brownlow already has an early frontrunner
text:
Source: FOX SPORTS WE MIGHT have only played one game this season, but the Brownlow Medal already has an early frontrunner. 
While Patrick Dangerfield and Nat Fyfe, who face off on Sunday evening, might be the last two winners of the award and the two favourites going into the year, it’s Dustin Martin who has set the pace in 2017. 
Richmond coach Damien Hardwick described Martin’s performance in Thursday night’s season-opener fixture against Carlton as “special”. 
It’s hard to find a better adjective to describe it. 
The on-baller racked up 33 disposals, six clearances and kicked four goals, selflessly dishing off two more to teammates throughout a comfortable 43-point win for the Tigers. 
LIVE stream every game of every round of the 2017 Toyota AFL Premiership Season on FOX SPORTS. Get your free 2-week FOXTEL PLAY trial and start watching in minutes. SIGN UP NOW >> 
It was an outing that highlighted just how important Martin can be when used forward of centre — something supporters hardly saw throughout a 2016 campaign in which he won most of his footy behind the ball. 
Able to roam free inside 50 following the handy acquisitions of Dion Prestia and Josh Caddy over the off-season, Martin had six inside 50s and only four rebounds — reflective of where he was able to damage the opposition at the MCG. 
“He’s a very good player,” Hardwick said after the match. 
“He kicked four and gave off two, so it was a pretty special sort of game. 
“The addition of Caddy and Prestia — it helps with Dusty being able to play more forward. Dion played really well tonight and Josh battled mercifully through the middle — his body use was first class and he smashed packs. 
“Sometimes one player is going to get the benefit of others’ good work. That’s not to say Dusty doesn’t do a lot of good work as well, but we’re happy with that.” Dustin Martin in action during the win over Carlton. (AAP Image/Julian Smith) Source: AAP 
Of course, Martin was aptly aided — as Hardwick said — by arguably the trade period’s two most shrewd recruits. 
Prestia, prized from Gold Coast, won 28 disposals to go with six clearances and a goal. 
Caddy, who arrived via Geelong, had 16 touches and also went forward to impact on the scoreboard. 
It allowed Martin more time to stream up the field from a position on the half forward flank — something he was hardly able to do throughout a 2016 season where he won more footy than ever, but hurt opposition teams less. 
In fact, last season was the first campaign in five years in which the midfielder didn’t average more than a goal per game. 
Martin finds himself out of contract at season’s end and headed into the year as one of the competition’s most sought-after free agents. 
Performances like the one he produced on Thursday night will surely only increase his value — which many believe is already worth in excess of $1 million per season. 
But, rather than become bogged down in free agency speculation — a trap many quality footballers have fallen into in the past — Hardwick praised Martin’s ability to focus purely on his football. 
“That’s what good players do,” Hardwick said. 
“He’s the ultimate professional. He goes about his business, trains incredibly hard and looks after himself. 
“He got the result he deserved tonight.” 
Richmond already has the most recent winner of a Brownlow Medal on its list. 
It might also have the next winner as well.
